meta.title: What Parenting Pattern Are You Running?
meta.description: Discover which intergenerational parenting pattern drives your default moves — whether you're replaying old scripts, rebelling against them, remixing the best parts, or building from scratch. No childhood therapy couch required.
meta.intro: Every parent runs a pattern, whether they know it or not. This quiz watches how you actually parent — not where it came from — and names the blueprint you're following.
meta.subject: you
meta.shareCta: Curious which parenting pattern you're running?

previewCta.title: Get your complete parenting pattern profile
previewCta.body: Your primary type, strengths, growth edge, and how you compare across all patterns.

previewPromises: Detailed description of your primary pattern
Your growth edge — one shift that changes the most
How you compare across all patterns

communityCta.title: Get scripts from parents doing the same work
communityCta.body: Real strategies, daily support from parents breaking cycles and building new ones. We are there with you daily too.

replayer.name: The Replayer
replayer.tagline: You parent on autopilot — the scripts are inherited, and they run fast.
replayer.description: When things get heated, your mouth opens and a familiar voice comes out. The phrases, the tone, the discipline moves — they feel like instinct, but they're muscle memory. You didn't sit down and choose this approach. It chose you, somewhere around the third meltdown.
strengths: You don't overthink every decision — you have a clear internal playbook
You bring consistency because your defaults are automatic and predictable
You have a concrete reference point when things get chaotic
replayer.growthEdge: Autopilot is efficient, but it doesn't filter. Some of those inherited scripts land differently on your kid than they did on you.
replayer.encouragement: Having defaults isn't the problem — running them without noticing is. You can keep the ones that work and swap out the ones that don't. That starts with hearing the script before it finishes playing.
replayer.comparativeContext: Most parents default to automatic responses under stress, especially during the toddler and preschool years.

rebel.name: The Rebel
rebel.tagline: You know exactly what you won't do — and that's your compass.
rebel.description: Your parenting is organized around a list of things you refuse to repeat. Harsh? You go gentle. Cold? You go warm. Rigid? You bend. Every choice gets measured against what you're determined to avoid. The vow is clear, even if you've never said it out loud.
strengths: You're intentional about breaking patterns that caused harm
You question inherited defaults instead of accepting them automatically
You're willing to be uncomfortable if it means parenting differently
rebel.growthEdge: Defining yourself by what you won't do can leave you reactive instead of grounded. Sometimes the opposite of a mistake is a different mistake.
rebel.encouragement: Rejecting the old blueprint is brave. But at some point you need your own foundation — not just the inverse of someone else's. The goal isn't to prove anything. It's to figure out what actually works for your kid.
rebel.comparativeContext: Parents who consciously reject their upbringing's approach often swing far in the other direction before settling into their own style.

remixer.name: The Remixer
remixer.tagline: You keep what works, ditch what doesn't, and build your own version.
remixer.description: You're selective and deliberate. Some of your defaults feel right, so you run with them. Others don't, so you swap them out. You're not on autopilot and you're not in rebellion — you're editing. Every response gets a quick audit before it leaves your mouth.
strengths: You make conscious choices instead of defaulting or rebelling
You can hold nuance — not everything inherited is bad, not everything is good
You adapt your approach based on what your kid actually needs
remixer.growthEdge: Even the best curation needs regular updates. The response that worked at three might backfire at seven, and the thing that felt right in theory can land wrong in practice.
remixer.encouragement: You've already done the hardest part — separating what you chose from what you inherited. Keep auditing. Nothing about parenting stays static, and the willingness to keep editing is the whole game.
remixer.comparativeContext: Parents who actively curate their approach tend to report higher confidence and lower guilt in their parenting decisions.

freestyler.name: The Freestyler
freestyler.tagline: You're building from scratch — books, friends, experiments, gut instinct.
freestyler.description: Your parenting toolbox is assembled from everywhere: podcasts, parenting accounts, friends' advice, trial and error. You don't run inherited scripts — you gather new ones, test them, and keep whatever sticks. Your approach changes as you learn, and you're fine with that.
strengths: You're open to new strategies and willing to change course when something isn't working
You respond to what your kid actually needs rather than what a script says
You're comfortable with uncertainty and treat parenting as an ongoing experiment
freestyler.growthEdge: Reinventing everything from scratch is exhausting. Not every new approach is better than the old one — sometimes the familiar response works fine.
freestyler.encouragement: Building your own playbook takes serious effort, and the willingness to keep learning is a real asset. Just make sure you're assembling a system, not just collecting techniques. A pile of strategies isn't the same as an approach.
freestyler.comparativeContext: Parents who build their own framework from scratch often report feeling more creative but also more decision fatigue.

questions.text: Your kid just broke a household rule. What's your first move?
questions.subtext: Not the ideal response — the one that actually happens.

options.text: You lay down the consequence immediately — firm, fast, no debate.
You pause and check yourself — you don't want to come down too hard, so you lead with empathy first.
You hold the boundary but acknowledge the feeling — firm and warm, not one or the other.
You think about the approach you've been reading about and try to apply it in the moment.

questions.text: Your child is melting down at a restaurant. The whole place is watching. What drives your response?

options.text: You shut it down quickly — a firm voice, a clear consequence, and you move on.
You scoop them up and leave. Forcing compliance in public feels wrong, even if it's inconvenient.
You get down to their level, validate the feeling quickly, and redirect — damage control without drama.
You assess what's happening — hungry? overstimulated? — and pick a strategy based on the trigger.

questions.text: Your kid screams 'I hate you!' during a meltdown. What happens inside your head?

options.text: Anger. That kind of talk is not acceptable and there needs to be a consequence.
You absorb it. They need to feel safe expressing big feelings, even ugly ones.
You hold the line on respect but don't punish the feeling — both things can be true.
You stay curious — what's underneath? You run through your mental toolkit for what to try.

questions.text: You just yelled at your kid. It's over, you're calm again. What's the first thing you do?

options.text: Move on. Kids need to learn that actions have consequences and sometimes adults get frustrated.
Apologize immediately. You swore you'd never yell and you need to make it right.
Repair. You name what happened, own your part, and reconnect without making it a bigger deal than it is.
Do a mental replay — what triggered that? What would the approach you've been studying suggest instead?

questions.text: Bedtime. Your kid wants you to stay. You've got nothing left. What wins?
questions.subtext: Be honest about the default, not the aspiration.

options.text: You stay briefly, say goodnight, close the door. The routine is the routine.
You stay as long as they need. Leaving a scared kid alone feels like the wrong call, full stop.
You stay long enough to settle them, offer a comfort object, and then step out — warmth plus a boundary.
You try whatever technique you're currently experimenting with — gradual retreat, breathing exercises, a story trick.

questions.text: Your child asks why they have to do something. How do you handle it?

options.text: 'Because I said so.' Not everything needs a rationale, and explaining every rule is exhausting.
You always explain your reasoning. Kids deserve to understand the why, not just the what.
You give a brief reason when it matters and hold the line without justification when it doesn't.
It depends on the situation — sometimes you explain, sometimes you don't, depending on what the moment calls for.

questions.text: Your kid hits their sibling and refuses to apologize. What's your play?

options.text: You insist on the apology. Hitting has consequences, and saying sorry is the minimum.
You skip the forced apology — it's meaningless if it's coerced. You help them process the feeling instead.
You address the harm, help with repair, and let the genuine apology come when they're ready — if it comes.
You pull from your conflict resolution toolkit — maybe it's a repair conversation, maybe a cool-down first, depends on the technique you're testing.

questions.text: You're stuck on a parenting decision and need direction. Where do you look first?

options.text: Your gut. You know what feels right because you've seen it done before.
You think about what would feel wrong to repeat — and rule that out first.
You weigh what feels right, what doesn't, and what makes sense for this specific kid in this specific moment.
Books, podcasts, friends, online communities — you gather input before committing to a move.
